etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in William Gladstone (1809–1898), prime minister and author. From ancient Greek ἀνθρωποϕυής of human nature (from ἀνθρωπο- + ϕυή growth, nature from the same base as ϕύειν to produce, (passive and intransitive) to grow) + -ism

definitions: The ascription of human characteristics or attributes to the gods or to the natural world.

notes.text: Chiefly in, or with reference to, the writings of W. E. Gladstone.
